intro: Blastocaulon scirpeum, commonly known as the marsh hollyhock, is a herbaceous plant native to wetland and marsh habitats. It belongs to the family Amaranthaceae and is characterized by its tall, branched stems and showy, pinkish-red flowers. The plant typically grows in shallow water or damp soil, thriving in environments with high humidity. Its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and often covered in fine hairs. Blastocaulon scirpeum plays an important ecological role by providing habitat and food for various aquatic and semi-aquatic organisms.
